msItem.author: Philip of Oxford
msItem.title: Miracula sancte Frideswide
msItem.note: Benjamin Bossue, ‘De sancta Frideswida virgine, patrona Oxoniensi in Anglia’, in Acta sanctorum Octobris, ed. Joseph van Heck et al., Acta sanctorum 55 (Brussels, 1853), 8.567–90.

msItem.title: Prologue
msItem.rubric: Incipit prologus domni philippi prioris de miraculis sancte frideswide.
msItem.incipit: Domini ac saluatoris nostri uirtus et sapientia tanto maioribus laudum preconiis attollitur⹎
msItem.explicit: leprosis mundatis ut ora sacerdotibus ostenderent preceptum est.

msItem.title: The translation of St Frideswide, 12 February 1180
msItem.incipit: Scripturus itaque miracula que temporibus nostris
msItem.explicit: posterorum memorie arcius inprimatur.

msItem.title: Martin of Oxford sees a heavenly light
msItem.incipit: In pago oxenefordie erat uir quidam martinus nomine qui mercimonii
msItem.explicit: irradiationem totius prouintie que huiuscemodi signo preostensa est⹎ materialem ciuitatis arbitratus concremationem.

msItem.title: Edith of Oxford’s vision of a golden column, 1171/72
msItem.incipit: In eodem pago matrona quedam editha nomine. quantum ad huma num
msItem.explicit: euentus. cum in occiduis mundi partibus noui solis claritas exorta est.

msItem.title: The dream of Robert, Prior Philip’s relative, 1179?
msItem.incipit: Habebat prenominatus prior philippus famulum quendam consanguinitate sibi coniunctum
msItem.explicit: pagina presens excrescat. presertim cum ad describendas eius uirtutes⹎ mea festinat intentio.

msItem.title: The daughter of Geoffrey Pady healed of a swollen neck, the night of 12–13 February 1180
msItem.incipit: Cum igitur ut predictum est pridie idus februarii gloriose translationis
msItem.explicit: admiratione et gaudio in breue tempus omnimodis sanitati restituta est.

msItem.title: Alice of Oxford sees on Maundy Thursday, 17 April 1180?
msItem.incipit: Erat in eodem pago iuuencula quedam adelitia nomine
msItem.explicit: curata est⹎ ut in ea nulla prorsus egritudinis pristine

msItem.title: William of Wales recovers from a bent back
msItem.incipit: Venerat illuc diebus illis de partibus Walliarum uir quidam
msItem.explicit: ad plenum conualuit⹎ quod ad dominicum sepulcrum. adeundum iter incolumis arripuit.

msItem.title: William of Ardley cured of various ailments
msItem.incipit: Erat in uico quodam cui uocabulum est herduluesleie
msItem.explicit: et a prenominatis eum pror sus incommodis respirasse⹎ ipsa rerum experientia didicimus.

msItem.title: Haimo de Saint-Cyr cured of three ailments on Easter, 20 April 1180
msItem.incipit: Per idem tempus hoc quoque mirabile et memoria dignum accidit.
msItem.explicit: frequenter dum ei famulari compellebantur⹎ calamitatum suarum uexauerat et tedio affecerat inmanitas.

msItem.title: Winneva of Heythrop healed of dropsy
msItem.incipit: Cum itaque talium signorum circumquaque fama crebresceret⹎ ob gratiam recuperande sanitatis
msItem.explicit: sanitatis recepte uentrem qui prorsus resederat. populo gaudente palam cunctis ostenderet.

msItem.title: Reinildis of Abingdon cured of swelling
msItem.incipit: Hisdem temporibus mulier quedam de abbendonia Reinildis nomine
msItem.explicit: aliquantulum prominebat. que tamen postmodum temporis proces su prorsus abolita est.

msItem.title: Raganilda of Burford cured of various ailments
msItem.incipit: Venit et ob gratiam recuperande sanitatis puella quedam de Burefordia Raganilda nomine
msItem.explicit: simul incommodo. non sine omnium qui tunc aderant admiratione prorsus inmunis.

msItem.title: Brithiva of Haverhill and Eve of Gatehampton cured
msItem.incipit: Sed et hoc laudibus eius non inmerito annectendum uidetur qui ante
msItem.explicit: morte liberat. hic quidem in spe⹎ in futuro autem in re.

msItem.title: The sisters Turkiva and Seilda, of Eynsham, see
msItem.incipit: Erant in uilla cui nomen est Einesham due sorores quarum altera
msItem.explicit: uiderant˷ iam a domino curatas non sine admiratione et gaudio cernebant.

msItem.title: Azelina of Pillerton cured of paralysis
msItem.incipit: Eodem tempore uirgo quedam de normannia oriunda. etate quidem adulta
msItem.explicit: que eam paulo ante paraliticam uiderat⹎ et iam repente sanatam admirabatur.

msItem.title: Matilda cured of illnesses
msItem.incipit: Accidit insuper in eadem beate uirginis ecclesia eo dem die et
msItem.explicit: ad dei laudes inuitauit. qui sanctam uirginem suam tanta miraculorum gloria mirificabat.

msItem.title: Raganildis of East Anglia walks
msItem.incipit: Puella quedam Raganildis nomine de terra gloriosi patris et martiris
msItem.explicit: et liberauit in pondere montes et colles in statera.

msItem.title: Christina of Ampney healed from pain
msItem.incipit: His diebus mulier quedam de ameneia Cristina nomine per unius
msItem.explicit: clarandam manifestius dei uirtutem sanationem suam intuentium animis repetitis frequentius incuruationibus inculcans.

msItem.title: Emma of Exeter cured of dropsy
msItem.incipit: Quedam paupercula mulier Emma nomine de partibus exonie cum partum
msItem.explicit: quenter euenit ut diuine miserationis opem pre oculis semper habere nouerint.

msItem.title: William of Lincoln walks
msItem.incipit: Ad laudem insuper diuine pietatis accedit accidit stupendum quod subnectitur mira
msItem.explicit: illum pre omnibus locum amplectens ubi munus curationis acceperat.

msItem.title: The daughter of Richild of Winchester walks during vespers
msItem.incipit: Accidit eodem die et aliud dignum relatu mirabile.
msItem.explicit: sicut gesta erat oculata fide cernentes⹎ non inmerito laudes laudibus accumularunt.

msItem.title: Eustace of Coleshill cured of madness on the Invention of the Cross, 3 May
msItem.incipit: Hoc quoque relatu dignum arbitror. quod in preclara salutifere crucis
msItem.explicit: omni furoris molestia et capitis concussione liberum prorsus et inmunem.

msItem.title: Fulk Grove’s son returned to life on the Invention of the Cross, 3 May
msItem.incipit: Sed et de hoc quod eodem die contigit signo dei
msItem.explicit: uires que in eo penitus defecerant⹎ singulis reformante momentis.

msItem.title: Leviva of Wroxton healed of a tumour and ill humours
msItem.incipit: Mulier quedam leuiua nomine de uilla que Wrokestan nuncupatur.
msItem.explicit: omnis abscessit et manuum pedumque debilitas in naturalem rediit potentiam.

msItem.title: Childiva of Enstone cured of a pain in her abdomen
msItem.incipit: Hisdem quoque diebus uxor uiri cuiusdam de Ennestan childiua nomine que
msItem.explicit: poterat per gloriose uirginis merita gratiam sanitatis adepta est.

msItem.title: Constance of Denchworth healed of intolerable headaches
msItem.incipit: Sed et puella quedam de dencheswrtha constantia nomine cum
msItem.explicit: sed accepte curationis benefitium mirantibus cunctis et uerbis ostentans et gestibus.

msItem.title: Leviva of Shoreham recovers from a fever and walks
msItem.incipit: Quedam etiam mulier leuiua nomine de uilla que Shoram nuncupatur nata.
msItem.explicit: dei laudes resonante⹎ qui in sanctis suis semper est et ubique mirabilis.

msItem.title: Emmeline of Eddington survives suicide and speaks, May 1180
msItem.incipit: Puella quedam Emelina nomine. etate adulta. de uilla quadam uocabulo
msItem.explicit: curatricis sue famulatui famulatu et corpore herens et affectu.

msItem.title: Richard of Winchester healed of paralysis
msItem.incipit: Carpentarius quidam de ciuitate Wintoniensi nomine Ricardus dum die
msItem.explicit: adeptus paucis interpositis diebus sine baculi sustentamento ad solum natale remeauit.

msItem.title: Alexis of Hereford healed of many ailments
msItem.incipit: Hisdem diebus iuuenis quidam alexius nomine iuxta herefordiam natus per
msItem.explicit: utroque oculo res minutissimas utpote pilos et capillos deo donante discerneret.

msItem.title: Godwin of Watchfield hears and speaks at matins
msItem.incipit: Sed et iuuenis quidam de Wathnesfelda Godwinus nomine cum subiti casus
msItem.explicit: loquentium labia ad loquendum formari uidens⹎ non autem uerba loquentium discernens.

msItem.title: Isabella of Beachampton, wife to an adulterous man, healed after childbirth
msItem.incipit: Mulier quedam ysabella nomine de becchamtuna iuxta bukingeham cum ab
msItem.explicit: grauedine quam ab omni febrili calore se prorsus liberam testata est.

msItem.title: Beatrice of Wroughton healed of abdominal pain
msItem.incipit: Eodem die mulier quedam Beatrix nomine de ellendona uiro copulata
msItem.explicit: oratione persistens. mane facto ab omni dolore se liberam cunctis ostendit.

msItem.title: Margaret, Roger fitz Ralph of Stratton’s daughter, cured of scrofula on Ascension Day, 29 May 1180
msItem.incipit: Miles quidam Rogerus nomine filius Radulfi de uilla cui nomen
msItem.explicit: deciperet animam illius. ualitudine correpta⹎ migrauit a seculo.

msItem.title: Mabel of Shifford healed outside the church door on Ascension Day, 29 May 1180
msItem.incipit: Eodem die cum missarum agerentur sollempnia mulier quedam de Sifford
msItem.explicit: et post dies paucos gaudens ad propria remeauit.

msItem.title: The death of Deulecresse fil Moses, a young Jewish man in Oxford, the night of 29–30 May 1180
msItem.incipit: Nec silentio pretereunda est ultio quam dominus in quodam iudaice
msItem.explicit: qui a se dei scientiam reppulerunt qui gratis odio deum habuerunt.

msItem.title: John of Chadlington healed after coming near to death, June 1180
msItem.incipit: Cum his et aliis signorum mirabilibus uirtutem operum suorum populo suo
msItem.explicit: representabat deum qui est benedictus in secula⹎ deuotissime benedicens.

msItem.title: Cecilia, John of Chadlington’s wife, gives birth
msItem.incipit: Habebat idem iohannes uxorem nomine ceciliam claris natalibus propagatam.
msItem.explicit: que de tenebris infideles uocat in admirabile lumen suum.

msItem.title: Walter of Oxford healed of quinsy
msItem.incipit: Erat eodem tempore iuuenis quidam Walterus nomine beate uirginis
msItem.explicit: redderetur. ilico resti tuta sibi potestate. cibos incorporandi quam penitus amiserat.

msItem.title: Wulviva of Abingdon healed before the archbishop’s Mass
msItem.incipit: Talium itaque signorum fama crebrescente. uir uenerabilis dominus Ricardus cantuariensis
msItem.explicit: translatione uirginis sue gratum sibi idem uenerabilis pater exhibuerat obsequium.

msItem.title: A blind woman from London sees during the same Mass
msItem.incipit: Eodem die mulier quedam de partibus londoniarum ob salutem recuperandam
msItem.explicit: et que ceca uenerat⹎ deo et uirgini sue gratias referens incolumis discessit.

msItem.title: Matilda of Northampton sees on Pentecost, 8 June 1180?
msItem.incipit: Nec uacat a laude uirginis insigne miraculum quod euenit. die
msItem.explicit: quos consanguinitatis necessitudine puella contingebat. fidem omnium. assertionis sue testimonio roborantes.

msItem.title: An adulteress cannot see the church door
msItem.incipit: Succedunt mirabilibus. mirabilia frequentia signorum⹎
msItem.explicit: mereri. quia confessionis antidoto⹎ cuiuslibet uulneris dolor. aufertur.

msItem.title: A thief cannot find the way out
msItem.incipit: Sicut autem hec de qua supra dictum est.
msItem.explicit: flectabantur⹎ donec uirtus diuina. ipso rerum euentu. palam cunctis innotuit.

msItem.title: Brichtiva of Northampton removes an ear blockage at St Margaret’s Well in Binsey
msItem.incipit: Mulier quedam de partibus Norhamtunie. Brichtiua nomine.
msItem.explicit: ecclesiam rediens. deumque benedicens. omnibus qui aderant se curatam ostendit;

msItem.title: Hawise of Shifford healed of a debilitating illness
msItem.incipit: Vir quidam de sipfordia filiam habe bat uocabulo hawisam. annorum
msItem.explicit: populis stupentibus ab omni languore se per merita uirginis liberata exhibuit.

msItem.title: Margaret of Shrewsbury walks
msItem.incipit: Venerat eisdem ferme diebus de partibus Salopesbirie mulier quedam margareta
msItem.explicit: et in robur pristinum menbrorum omnium redit debilitas.

msItem.title: Stephen of York, a student at Oxford, healed of a fever
msItem.incipit: Morabatur eo tempore apud oxenefordiam studiorum causa clericus quidam stephanus
msItem.explicit: conquieuit. et redeuntibus paulis per uiribus in breui ad plenum conualuit.

msItem.title: Wimarcha of Stoke cured of an intestinal pain
msItem.incipit: Sed et mulier quedam de Stoches Wimarcha nomine cum anno
msItem.explicit: cepit humoribus et deo gratias et beate uirgini referens omnino sana recessit.

msItem.title: The priest Ralph of Andover makes a votive candle
msItem.incipit: Sacerdos etiam quidam quidem de handeura Radulfus nomine cum per annum
msItem.explicit: uoti lichno se metiens. ab omni deo iuuante respirauit incommodo.

msItem.title: The priest Ralph of Andover makes a votive candle for his son, Robert
msItem.incipit: Sed et filius eiusdem sacerdotis febrili tremore per integrum mensem
msItem.explicit: se usus beneficio⹎ per uirginis beate merita statim liberatus est.

msItem.title: The subdeacon Thomas of Andover makes a votive candle
msItem.incipit: Quidam etiam de uico eodem subdiaconus thomas nomine eadem qua
msItem.explicit: quod humana non potuit⹎ diuina se manu liberatum gaudens predicabat.

msItem.title: Emma of Southampton healed of paralysis
msItem.incipit: Ad laudem insuper et gloriam uirginis sue hoc etiam dominus operari
msItem.explicit: deum qui in sanctis suis gloriosus est benedicentibus⹎ constanti uoce professa est.

msItem.title: Thomas of Warminster cured of a debilitating swelling
msItem.incipit: His etiam diebus uir quidam de Wereministra thomas nomine qui uentositate
msItem.explicit: plenum et perfectum inbecillitatis sue remedium per merita gloriose uirginis consecutus est.

msItem.title: Alice of Breighton cured of harmful humours
msItem.incipit: Quedam etiam mulier de Bricchetona Adelicia nomine cum longo tempore noci
msItem.explicit: penitus residente sanitati pristine se restitu tam esse gauisa est.

msItem.title: Agnes of Duns Tew healed in one eye only
msItem.incipit: Hoc quoque pretereundum non est quod in muliere quadam
msItem.explicit: oculus mulieri redditus non sit⹎ ipse nouit cuius iudicia sunt abyssus multa.

msItem.title: Agnes of Bristol regains the use of her hands
msItem.incipit: Illo quoque tempore mulier quedam de Bristou Agnes nomine sancte uirginis
msItem.explicit: benedicta manus lauit tumor omnis abcessit. et amissa manuum rediit habilitas.

msItem.title: Emma of St Albans cured of a paralysed arm
msItem.incipit: Puella quedam de terra beati anglorum prothomartiris albani emma nomine.
msItem.explicit: restituta est. naturali redeunte potentia et nature defectum⹎ uirtute reformante diuina.

msItem.title: Peter of Marlborough cured of sciatica during matins
msItem.incipit: Sed nec hoc silendum arbitror quod iuueni cuidam de merleburga
msItem.explicit: ut nichil in se pristine debilitatis siue doloris remansisse publice protestaretur.

msItem.title: A boy from Leicestershire sees
msItem.incipit: His et aliis signorum preclara uirgo portentis. fame sue gloriam longe
msItem.explicit: diuine manus operationem predicans. quam oculata fide facillimum erat agnoscere.

msItem.title: Thurben of Holywell, a fuller, goes mad after a headache and is cured
msItem.incipit: Predictis adiciendum est et hoc insigne miraculum quo in ciuitate
msItem.explicit: exibendum gratiorem domino famulatum. ut sepulcrum adiret dominicum. iter arripuit.

msItem.title: Richard of Alton healed from bowel pains, alongside his daughter
msItem.incipit: Eodem tempore uir quidam de Aweltona ricardus nomine ad beate
msItem.explicit: est dominus. ne de sua gaudens curatione. filie pater lugeret erumpnas.

msItem.title: Emma of Pyrton healed of swollen limbs
msItem.incipit: Sed et femina quedam de uilla cui nomen est
msItem.explicit: nomen inuocans. tandem hausta aqua benedicta uomitus beneficio prorsus sanata est.

msItem.title: Agnes of Southampton cured of dropsy
msItem.incipit: Sicut autem propinquis sic et remotis uniuersitatis conditor uirginis sue
msItem.explicit: quiescente deum benedicens sana et incolumis ad propria cum gaudio rediit.

msItem.title: The daughter of Robert of Churchover healed from a fever
msItem.incipit: Filia etiam cuiusdam militis nomine roberti⹎ de Wauera
msItem.explicit: aliquomodo medicorum curari posset opera⹎ in ecclesia beate uirginis perfecte curata est.

msItem.title: A girl from Warwickshire healed of epilepsy
msItem.incipit: Quedam insuper puella de Wariwikesira ob sanitatem recuperandam illuc aduenit.
msItem.explicit: gauderet⹎ iterato beatam uirginem adiret. ut grates ei de sua referret curatione.

msItem.title: Ediva of Wanborough receives her sight; Henry of Wanborough uses his right hand and foot
msItem.incipit: Mulier quedam de Wanburg’ Ediua nomine religionis speciem
msItem.explicit: pueri agnouerant debilitatem et de utriusque curatione nobiscum deo gratias egerunt.

msItem.title: Aluitha of Dorchester recovers from dropsy
msItem.incipit: Mulier quedam de Dorchecestria aluitha nomine cum febrium dolore
msItem.explicit: et aliquantis ibi diebus moram fecis set⹎ miserante deo prorsus curata est.

msItem.title: Thorsten of Wycombe healed from a fever
msItem.incipit: Iuuenis quidam de Wicumba turstinus nomine febrium cruciatu integro fatigatus
msItem.explicit: publice cunctis qui aderant audientibus et diuinam laudantibus uirtutem protestatus est.

msItem.title: A boy from Wycombe sees
msItem.incipit: Hisdem diebus puerulus quidam biennis a parentibus in confinio Wicumbe
msItem.explicit: gratie sibi collate quod lingua non poterat facto testimonium nesciens perhibuit.

msItem.title: A traveller from Winchester falls ill on avoiding the church
msItem.incipit: Hoc quoque quod subnectitur signo dominus declarauit deuotionem sibi placere
msItem.explicit: et ad perficiendum quod eos urgebat negotium uires in integrum restituit.

msItem.title: Albreia of Fulbrook lifts her feet
msItem.incipit: Virgo quedam Albreia nomine de uico quodam cui uocabulum est Fulebroc
msItem.explicit: dei uiderent munere⹎ quod nec etatis beneficio. nec medicorum recuperare potuerat artificio.

msItem.title: Margaret of Collingbourne recovers from an abdominal illness
msItem.incipit: Clericus quidam Gaufridus nomine. de uilla cui nomine en est
msItem.explicit: limina adiuit. et cura tricem suam denuo rediens sanitati plene restituta uisitauit.

msItem.title: Richard Pauncefoot’s left hand and arm restored
msItem.incipit: Miles quidam Ricardus cognomento Pantefot. genere clarus. amplis possessionibus
msItem.explicit: ponderosas librabat. et sic in dei laudes cor da fidelium excitauit.

msItem.title: Hawise of Faringdon sees after two pilgrimages
msItem.incipit: Erat in uico cui nomen est ferendona puella quedam Hawisa nomine
msItem.explicit: sibi oblatas et uidere posset et discernere.

msItem.title: A young girl from Woburn recovers her sight
msItem.incipit: His et aliis operum suorum mirabilibus uirginis sue merita dominus
msItem.explicit: qui aderant exultantibus et dei magnalia cum gaudio personantibus.

msItem.title: Goda of Warwick healed of a skin disease
msItem.incipit: His adiciendum arbitror quod in uidua quadam Goda nomine de partibus
msItem.explicit: sanie spem perfecte curationis omnibus eam intuentibus interuentu beate uirginis prebuit.

msItem.title: The son of Mauger of Gloucester recovers from paralysis
msItem.incipit: Vir quidam malgerus nomine de partibus claudiocestrie filium habebat an norum
msItem.explicit: subita curationis nouitate nec dum a stupore prehabito plene conualuerat.

msItem.title: A woman from Inglesham healed of sores
msItem.incipit: Mulier quedam de uico cui nomen est inglesham sic ulceribus per
msItem.explicit: sanitati se resti tutam quantum uerecundia permittebat ipsa sui corporis ostensione protestabatur.

msItem.title: Cecilia of Salden recovers from a fever
msItem.incipit: Puella quoque nomine cecilia de uilla que saldena nuncupatur.
msItem.explicit: et incolumis ad propria remeauit. nichil in se pristine ualitudinis representans.

msItem.title: Agnes of Farthinghoe walks
msItem.incipit: Venerat illuc eisdem diebus uxor uiri cuiusdam agnes nomine de Ennestan
msItem.explicit: est ita quod nullo eam sustentante libere quo uolebat gressus dirigeret.

msItem.title: A woman from Wednesbury hears
msItem.incipit: Sed et mulier quedam de uico cui nomen est Wothnesberia
msItem.explicit: recepta potestate uerba submisse loquentium et audiret et cum omni facilitate discerneret.

msItem.title: Alviva recovers from insanity
msItem.incipit: Sed et mulier quedam Alueua nomine uiro copulata triennio furoris
msItem.explicit: et deo gratias agens⹎ sana et incolumis ad propria remeauit.

msItem.title: Alice of Tackley hears
msItem.incipit: Est uicus non longe a pago oxenefordie distans cui tacheleia
msItem.explicit: Audiendi recepto mu nere. saniei fluxu restricto et fetoris horrore funditus represso.

msItem.title: Hawise of Wolford recovers from depression
msItem.incipit: Hisdem quoque diebus puella quedam hawisa nomine de uico cui Wlwarda
msItem.explicit: sanitate recessisset⹎ demum rediens. ilico uomitus beneficio prorsus liberata est.

msItem.title: Alice of Ashbury recovers her strength
msItem.incipit: Eodem die quedam alia puella Adelicia nomine. de uilla que asseberia
msItem.explicit: et non multo post a nimia qua diutius oppressa fuerat debilitate. respirauit.

msItem.title: Swethiva of Bierton walks
msItem.incipit: Virgo quedam de uico cui Burtuna nomen est. iuxta
msItem.explicit: dolore et infestatione renum inmunis ad solum natale cum gaudio remeauit.

msItem.title: Godiva of Lus Hill healed of a headache and walks
msItem.incipit: Mulier quedam Godiua nomine de uilla quadam iuxta crikeladam que lustella
msItem.explicit: plebs fidelis excitata⹎ in dei laudes gaudens et exultans erupit.

msItem.title: Hawise of Newbury recovers her sight
msItem.incipit: Adhuc gloriose uirginis merita multitudo signorum ostendit. et fidelium animos
msItem.explicit: dextri labe purgata. ciliorum deformitate detersa. omnimodam sanitatem deo miserante sortita est.

msItem.title: Hugelina of Oxford healed of a fever
msItem.incipit: Non longe a pago oxenefordie uirgo quedam hugelina nomine febrium ardore
msItem.explicit: modico tamen interiecto tempore tortionum quiescentibus aculeis ab omni dolore liberata est.

msItem.title: Agnes of Sarsden walks
msItem.incipit: Sed et puella quedam agnes nomine de uilla que sicherestan nuncupatur
msItem.explicit: cum gaudio redire permisit. nullis in ea prehabite uexationis remanentibus omnino uestigiis.

msItem.title: Christiana of Northleach healed of an intermittent illness
msItem.incipit: Erat in uilla cui lecche nomen est uirgo quedam triennio
msItem.explicit: et beneficii singularis leticiam professione publica gaudium fecit esse commune.

msItem.title: Sibyl of Wendover healed of gout in her hands
msItem.incipit: Fuit et in uilla cui Wendoura nomen est mulier quedam uocabulo
msItem.explicit: casu recidisset⹎ iterato per dei gratiam et beate uirginis patrocinium curata est.

msItem.title: Helen of Ludgershall Castle recovers from piercing pain
msItem.incipit: Mulier quedam helena nomine de finibus castri cui Lutegareshala uocabulum est.
msItem.explicit: deleuit. et intellectum quem sanitatis munus preripuerat. egritudinis molesti a restituit.

msItem.title: William of Shrivenham healed from syncope
msItem.incipit: Sed et iuueni cuidam Willelmo nomine de uilla que
msItem.explicit: restitutus est. uiribus corporis reparatis. recedentibus omnino pristine debilitatis et defectus erumpnis.

msItem.title: Christiana of Dean walks
msItem.incipit: Nec alicui uideatur onerosa miraculorum numerositas. cum diuine manus operationem
msItem.explicit: donata deo sueque curatrici gratias agens⹎ domum incolumis reuersa est.

msItem.title: Hugh of Shrewsbury healed of epilepsy
msItem.incipit: Vir quidam de partibus salopesberie hugo nomine quatuor ferme mensibus
msItem.explicit: cum perfecte dei munus cognouisset⹎ gaudens et exultans deum que benedicens abcessit.

msItem.title: Leviva of Lockinge walks
msItem.incipit: Mulier quedam de uico qui lakinges nuncupatur leuiua nomine sinistro pede
msItem.explicit: repentine mutationis baculum cui innisa fuerat beate uirgini quasi pro munere obtulit.

msItem.title: Doubtful healings left untold
msItem.incipit: Non nulli etiam utriusque sexus quos uiscerum dolor miserabiliter torquebat.
msItem.explicit: morbis terminum non mira culo. sed secundum cursum solitum nature contigisse.

msItem.title: John, constable of Chester, healed of abdominal distension
msItem.incipit: Licet autem scriptura testante ignobilia mundi huius deus
msItem.explicit: tum sibi celitus beneficium uoce publica fidelium auribus inculcans.

msItem.title: Margaret, wife of Richard fitz Gerald, finds her holy water transformed into milk
msItem.incipit: Sicut autem omnipotentis dei manus nouas cotidie creat. essentias. sic
msItem.explicit: quia candore castitatis. odo rem sui nominis. longe lateque diffudit.

msItem.title: Prior Philip recovers from a tertian fever
msItem.incipit: Cum igitur aliis exhibita curationis remedia. loquatur os me um
msItem.explicit: ut in aliis dei gratiam quam in me fueram expertus⹎ facilius crederem.

msItem.title: Agnes of Leicester cured of fever and madness
msItem.incipit: Habebat aurifaber quidam iuo nomine de pago leicestrie uxorem agnetem nomine
msItem.explicit: quod fecerat. operum executione demum compleuit. deique uirtutem palam populis annunciauit.

msItem.title: Mabel, wife of William Achard, healed of dropsy
msItem.incipit: Sed nec silere iustum est operis diuini uirtutem quam in nobi
msItem.explicit: uisitauit ecclesiam. collatum sibi celitus beneficium clara uoce constanter exponens.

msItem.title: Emma of Wheatley healed of a spiritual ailment
msItem.incipit: Alia quoque spectabilis femina emma nomine domina uille cui Wateleia
msItem.explicit: Itaque continuate salutis adeptioni congaudens dei gratiam ore predicabat et mente.

msItem.title: Laurence Kepeharm survives surgery
msItem.incipit: Hoc quoque quam stupendum sub silentio pretereundum non arbitror esse miraculum.
msItem.explicit: nobis in tante uirtutis testimonium ostenderunt;

msItem.title: Acrostic hexameter poem on FRIDESVVIDA

lg.l: Fontem/ in sicco fundo a domino impetrauit
Visum dederit militibus/ quos prius excecauit
In silua per triennium cum sponso id est cristo habitauit

msItem.note: Anthony Wood, Survey of the Antiquities of the City of Oxford, ed. Andrew Clark, Oxford Historical Society 17 (Oxford, 1889), ii. 134.

msItem.title: Hexameter acrostics on FRIDESVVIDA, forming mnemonics for her miracles, set against the seven vices

list.item:
Contra superbiam
Filia. Regalis. Iuris. Datur. Esse. Sodalis.
Venti. Venalis. Iacturam. Depulit. Alis.

Contra iram
Fons. Redit. Immemores. Ducunt. Exemplum. Sapores.
Vincunt. Vltores. Inuios. Dicentis. Amores.

Contra inuidiam
Fer. Ruit. Inuidie. Dampnabilis. Ense. Salutis.
Viscera. Virtutis. Iam. Dat. Amicicie.

Contra accidiam
Factoris. Recolens. Iusti. Deuocius. Egit.
Summa. Videre. Volens. Iuga. Dissuadentis. Abegit.

Contra auariciam
Fatales. Retum. Iactus. Despexit Egena.
Sorte. Virum. Verum. Iustum. Dilexit. Amena.

Contra gulam
Fauces. Restrinxit. In Deliciis. Epularum.
Sic. Ventrem. Vincit. Ita. Dulcoratus. Amarum.

Contra luxuriam
Flos. Redolens. Iuit. Ductor. Enigma. Sequta.
Virgula. Vestiuit. Imbres. Dilexit. Acuta.

supportDesc.foliation: Foliated in modern pencil, 1–30. deseruire uiderentur
supportDesc.collation: a2, 1–38 (fols 1–24), 46–1+1 (fols 25–30; 3rd replaced), b2. The first leaf of each quire is lettered a–d at the foot.

layoutDesc.layout: 185 119 Ruled in pencil and plummet; pricking on all edges of the page for frame and lines, spaced 5.5 mm apart. Horizontal rules occur from top to bottom (fol. 2r) at 33.5 | 39 | 44.5 | 21.75 | 207 | 212.75 | 273; vertical rules, from left to right, 20 | 24 | 79.5 | 84 | 88.5 | 142 | 146.5 | 191.5. Written above top line.

handDesc.handNote: Protogothic script. The first phase of production may have been limited to the two quires, with the following sections added in at least two later phases.

Chap. 106 (fols 28v–30r) is written in a darker shade of ink, probably added to the volume shortly after its creation. The same shade of ink is used to make numerous corrections to the text, particularly adding punctuation to assist oral reading (sometimes the additions are overpunctuated in comparison to the original text).

decoDesc.decoNote: Text opens with an 8-line arabesque initial in red and green. Subsequent chapters open with 2-line initials, generally alternating between blue and red.

Along with letters added plummet to direct the rubricator, there are numbers whose function is unclear: iii in the margin of fol. 10rb; iii, fol. 17rb; iiii, fol. 17va; iii, fol. 18ra; iiii and viii, fol. 18rb.

additions.p: The manuscript includes what appear to be autograph revisions to the text rather than corrections from an exemplar, most notably in his account of the translation of Frideswide’s relics on fol. 2ra, and what appears to be an extended addition at the foot of fols 15v–16r.

Anthony Wood began to number the sections implied by the drop capitals in ink. He refers to the text in his Survey of the Antiquities of the City of Oxford. A reader completed the chapter numbers in pencil in the 20th century, but these are only accurate up to 87, since they skip back to 80 at fol. 24v.

binding.p: Standard Digby binding (Delisle type I). Brass clasps.
binding.decoNote: Decorated with Digby’s arms, surrounded by wreath, with legend INSIGNIA KENELMI DIGBY EQVITIS AVRATI ✠.

origPlace.orgName: Oxford, Augustinian priory of St Frideswide

origin.p: The manuscript’s first two quires (fols 1–16) are datable between the contested consecration of John the Scot as bishop of St Andrews on 15 June 1180 and his resignation in June 1183. The scribe of chapter 1 records him as bishop-elect at the time of the translation of St Frideswide (12 February 1180) and afterwards bishop (postmodum autem episcopo, fol. 2r), but the second statement was subsequently erased, reflecting the papal settlement of 1183. The text also refers to Roger, abbot of Abingdon, who died in 1185 (ch. 42).

While there is no specific evidence for the manuscript’s place of origin, its multiple stages of copying, original revisions, and liturgical markings show that the book was at St Frideswide’s Priory immediately after its initial creation, though it remains possible that the priory commissioned the first two quires. The effaced inscription at the head of fol. 1r is legible with multispectral imaging as a guide for the decorator in the text hand, Domini ac saluatoris.

The book was still at St Frideswide’s in the 14th century, since it was available to the compiler of De sancta Fredeswida uirgine (BHL 3166) in the Romsey Legendary (London, British Library, Lansdowne MS 436). This text includes extracts from MS Digby 177 and concludes with an enumeration of its contents, indicating that the reader may find them in libro translacionis et miraculorum beate uirginis Frideswide (Lansdowne MS 436, fol. 103v). The Romsey Legendary refers to several books in local shrines.

history.provenance: Thomas Allen (MS fº 7); Allen/Digby inventory A 14: inscribed, fol. 1r. Many of Allen’s manuscripts were from Oxford, and he owned other books from shrines; cf. Michael Foster, ‘Thomas Allen (1540–1632), Gloucester Hall and the Survival of Catholicism in Post-Reformation Oxford’, Oxoniensia, 46 (1981): 99–128.
Kenelm Digby: inscribed, with his motto, Vindica te tibi (fol. 1r).

recordHist.source: Description by Andrew Dunning (January 2020; revised May 2025). Previously described in the Quarto Catalogue (W. D. Macray, Bodleian Library Quarto Catalogues IX: Digby Manuscripts, repr. with addenda by R. W. Hunt and A. G. Watson, 1999). Quarto Catalogue, col. 190 Quarto Catalogue (addenda), p. 82 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 1, p. 75

revisionDesc.change: Mitch Fraas Provenance and acquisition information added using https://github.com/littlegustv/oxfordupdates/blob/master/test_case_for_oxford_prov.rb in collaboration with the Mapping Manuscript Migrations project.
James Cummings Up-converted the markup using https://github.com/jamescummings/Bodleian-msDesc-ODD/blob/master/convertTolkien2Bodley.xsl
